notes: Security deposit laws and typical practices in major US cities. All values represent multipliers of one month's rent.

sources: New York State Attorney General - Tenant Rights

state_laws.exceptions: Small landlords (max 2 units) may collect up to 2 months
No statewide limit; check city ordinances (e.g., Chicago RLTO)
sources: Illinois General Assembly - Security Deposit Return Act

state_laws.exceptions: No statewide limit on deposit amount

city_practice.notes: Strictly limited to 1 month by state law since 2019. No additional prepaid rent allowed.

sources: NY Housing Stability and Tenant Protection Act

city_practice.notes: AB 12 recently reduced the cap from 2 to 1 for most landlords regardless of furniture.
Landlords often charge a non-refundable move-in fee instead of a security deposit to avoid strict interest payment laws.

sources: Chicago Residential Landlord and Tenant Ordinance (RLTO)

city_practice.notes: No legal cap in Texas; amount is usually determined by the tenant's credit score.
Landlords cannot require more than 1.5 times the monthly rent for a deposit per state law.

sources: Arizona Residential Landlord and Tenant Act

city_practice.notes: Capped at 2 months for the first year of the lease and 1 month for subsequent years.
Standard practice follows Texas law with no specific city-level cap.
Under CA AB 12, security deposits are now limited to one month's rent for most properties.
No state cap; standard practice is one month's rent but can be higher for low credit.
Follows California state mandate limiting deposits to one month of rent.
Highly competitive market; some properties offer deposit insurance as an alternative to cash deposits.
Florida has no statutory limit on security deposit amounts for residential leases.
Follows general Texas property code without additional municipal limits.
Ohio law does not cap the deposit, but interest must be paid if it exceeds one month's rent.
Indiana does not have a legal limit on the amount of security deposit collected.
Capped at 1.5x for month-to-month and 2x for leases longer than two months.
Historically high, but now strictly limited to 1x rent due to new state legislation.
City law requires landlords to allow tenants to pay deposits and fees in installments.
Colorado law does not cap the deposit amount; market standard is usually one month.
Oklahoma law provides no maximum limit for security deposits.

sources: Oklahoma Residential Landlord and Tenant Act

city_practice.notes: Tennessee has no statutory limit on security deposits, but one month is standard practice.
Follows general Texas law with no cap; deposits are often tied to credit screening results.
D.C. law strictly limits security deposits to a maximum of one month's rent.
Nevada law limits security deposits to a maximum of three months' rent.
Massachusetts law limits the security deposit to one month's rent and requires interest payments.
No state cap, but landlords must provide a written list of all deposits and fees.
Kentucky has no limit on the deposit amount, but funds must be held in a separate account.
Standard practice in Memphis is a deposit equal to one month's rent.
Michigan law limits security deposits to 1.5 times the monthly rent.
Maryland law limits security deposits to two months' rent; exceeding this allows for triple damages.
Wisconsin law does not set a maximum limit for security deposits.
Limited to one month for leases under a year; interest must be paid for deposits exceeding one month.
Subject to Arizona's state-wide 1.5x monthly rent cap.

sources: AZ Residential Landlord and Tenant Act

city_practice.notes: Follows California AB 12, limiting deposits to one month's rent as of July 2024.
New state law applies; landlords are limited to 1x rent for security deposits.
Missouri law limits security deposits to a maximum of two months' rent.
Regulated by the Arizona state cap of 1.5 times the monthly rent.
Georgia has no legal limit on security deposit amounts.
Nebraska law limits security deposits to a maximum of one month's rent.

sources: Nebraska Uniform Residential Landlord and Tenant Act

city_practice.notes: Colorado law does not cap the deposit amount; standard practice is one month's rent.
North Carolina law limits deposits to 2x rent for terms longer than month-to-month.
Subject to California's new AB 12 mandate limiting all residential deposits to 1 month.
Virginia law limits security deposits to a maximum of two months' rent.

sources: Virginia Residential Landlord and Tenant Act

city_practice.notes: Florida has no statutory limit; it is common for landlords to request first, last, and security.
Adheres to the 2024 CA statewide cap of one month's rent for security deposits.
Minnesota has no legal limit on deposit amounts, but interest must be paid to tenants.
Oklahoma state law does not impose a maximum limit on security deposits.

sources: Oklahoma Residential Landlord and Tenant Act

city_practice.notes: Regulated by California's 1-month rent cap for residential properties.
Kansas law limits unfurnished units to 1 month and furnished units to 1.5 months.

sources: Kansas Residential Landlord and Tenant Act

city_practice.notes: Standard Texas practice applies; no legal cap exists at the state or city level.
Colorado does not cap security deposits; market norms dictate a 1-month standard.
No state-wide limit in Florida; landlords have full discretion on the amount.

sources: FL Dept of Agriculture and Consumer Services

city_practice.notes: Louisiana law does not limit the amount a landlord can charge for a security deposit.
Ohio has no statutory limit; 1 month is the most common requirement.
Hawaii law limits the security deposit to a maximum of one month's rent.
Adheres to California Civil Code limiting deposits to one month of rent.
No legal limit on security deposit amounts in the state of Kentucky.
New California laws limit the deposit to 1x rent for nearly all residential units.
Follows general Texas law; no cap is placed on security deposit amounts.
Subject to Nevada's state cap of 3 months' rent for security deposits.
In accordance with California AB 12, the security deposit is capped at one month's rent for residential leases.
New Jersey state law strictly limits security deposits to a maximum of 1.5 times the monthly rent.
Minnesota law has no maximum limit on deposit amounts; one month is the prevailing market standard.
Effective July 2024, California law prohibits security deposits exceeding one month's rent for most landlords.
Ohio does not cap the security deposit amount. Interest is required if the deposit exceeds one month's rent.
Managed properties in Irvine strictly follow the new CA state-wide 1-month rent deposit cap.
Florida state law provides no limit on security deposit amounts; often depends on the landlord's policy.
Pennsylvania law limits deposits to 2 months' rent for the first year and 1 month for subsequent years.

sources: PA Landlord and Tenant Act of 1951

city_practice.notes: Missouri law limits security deposits to a maximum of two months' rent.
North Carolina law caps security deposits at 2 months' rent for leases longer than month-to-month.
Jersey City landlords are bound by the state-wide 1.5 month security deposit maximum.
Alaska law limits deposits to 2 months' rent unless the monthly rent exceeds $2,000.
Nebraska law restricts security deposits to a maximum of one month's rent.

sources: Nebraska Residential Landlord and Tenant Act

city_practice.notes: In Plano, there is no legal limit on deposits; corporate landlords usually require one month.
Regulated by North Carolina state law which allows up to 2 months' rent for security.
State-wide New York law limits security deposits to one month's rent for all residential leases.

sources: NY State Attorney General Housing Guide

city_practice.notes: Chandler landlords must adhere to the Arizona state cap of 1.5 times the monthly rent.
As part of California, security deposits are limited to 1 month's rent per the 2024 AB 12 legislation.
No statutory cap on security deposits in Ohio; 1 month's rent is the typical market requirement.
Wisconsin law does not impose a limit on the amount of security deposit landlords can charge.
Bound by Arizona state law which limits security deposits to 1.5 times the monthly rent.

sources: Arizona Residential Landlord and Tenant Act

city_practice.notes: Nevada law permits landlords to charge up to 3 months of rent as a security deposit.
No state-wide limit on security deposit amounts in Indiana; market standard is 1 month.
Subject to the Nevada state cap of 3 months' rent for all residential security deposits.
Florida has no legal cap on security deposits. Landlords typically request 1-2 months based on credit.
No statutory limit in Texas; amount varies by property management company policies.
Standard practice in Irving is one month's rent for qualified applicants with no legal state cap.
Follows general Texas law where there is no maximum limit for security deposits.
North Carolina law limits security deposits to 2 months' rent for standard lease terms.
Virginia state law limits the security deposit to a maximum of two months' rent.

sources: Virginia Residential Landlord and Tenant Act

city_practice.notes: Strictly adheres to the Arizona state cap of 1.5 months' rent for residential security deposits.
No legal limit on deposit amounts in Garland; depends on the landlord's screening criteria.
Regulated by Arizona law limiting deposits to 1.5x monthly rent.
Norfolk landlords must comply with the Virginia state cap of 2 months' rent.
Idaho law does not limit the security deposit amount. 1 month is standard.

sources: Idaho Office of the Attorney General

city_practice.notes: Subject to California AB 12, capping all residential security deposits at 1 month's rent.
Washington has no state cap, but Spokane landlords typically follow the 1-month market standard.
Complies with the 2024 California law limiting security deposits to a maximum of 1 month's rent.
Louisiana law provides no upper limit on the amount landlords can charge for deposits.
